metadata.case_name: Ashok Leyland Ltd. v. State of Madras

facts.text: The assessee is a firm Messrs. Ashok Leyland Ltd. with factory at Ennore in State of Madras, manufactures, assembles and sells motor vehicles, spare parts and accessories through organisation spread over several States.

Assessee appoints distributors called dealers with definite territorial jurisdiction inside and outside Madras; grants sole right to sell products within allotted territory; for out-of-State dealers, delivery by consignment by rail, steamer or road transport.
Agreement stipulates dealer must not canvass or sell outside territory; breach allows termination and return of unsold products.

In assessment year 1952-53 (April 1, 1951 to March 31, 1952), total turnover Rs. 1,43,67,007; Deputy CTO excluded Rs. 1,12,21,707 for out-of-State sales consigned by rail/steamer/road, taxed balance Rs. 31,45,299 at Rs. 1,45,655-13-3, paid by assessee.
Commercial Tax Officer, Madras, under s.12 Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939, revised assessment, proposed including Rs. 42,98,068 as deliveries within Madras.
Assessee objected, contended Rs. 42 lakhs sales in course of inter-State trade/commerce, not liable under Art. 286 Constitution; CTO overruled except small extent.
Appeal to Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal, Madras; Tribunal rejected jurisdiction plea but held Rs. 12,48,403 (vehicles driven by assessee's drivers to non-resident dealers) not taxable.

Revision to High Court of Madras under s.12B Act; challenged four items: (1) Rs. 1,43,072 vehicles delivered ex-factory to dealers' drivers, driven away after temporary registration outside Madras; (2) Rs. 28,01,357 vehicles to dealers' drivers under trade number, driven outside; (3) Rs. 7,866 spare parts/accessories with cars; (4) Rs. 15,000 spare parts consigned by rail/steamer outside.
High Court held first three items outside Art. 286(2) ban (taxable), fourth within ban (not taxable); judgment/order dated April 18, 1956 in Tax Revision Case No. 93 of 1955.
High Court granted certificate under Art. 133 Constitution for appeal to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the transactions in question (sales to out-of-State dealers with delivery within Madras) are protected by the ban in Art. 286(2) of the Constitution.
Whether the Sales Tax Laws Validation Act, 1956 applies to validate the tax on these inter-State sales during April 1, 1951 to September 6, 1955.

petitioner_arguments.text: Transactions in course of inter-State trade/commerce, not liable to tax under Art. 286(2).

Validation Act does not apply: (1) requires State law to expressly tax inter-State sales; (2) s.22 Madras Act (inserted 1957) limits to Explanation sales under Art. 286(1)(a) (goods delivered for consumption in State).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sales Tax Laws Validation Act, 1956 s.2; Madras General Sales Tax Act s.22

respondent_arguments.text: Deliveries made within State of Madras, taxable under Madras Act; not hit by Art. 286(2); Validation Act protects assessment.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939; Sales Tax Laws Validation Act, 1956

court_reasoning.text: Transactions within period of Validation Act (April 1, 1951 - Sept 6, 1955); s.2 lifts ban of Art. 286(2) notwithstanding any court judgment; State laws deemed valid even if sales inter-State.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Validation Act liberates State laws from Art. 286(2) fetter, enables operation on own terms.

court_reasoning.text: Rejects first petitioner argument: No need for express taxing of inter-State sales pre-Constitution; post-lift of ban, check if Madras Act on own terms taxes (yes, via definition of sale in s.2(h) Explanation 2, charging s.3).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act taxes sales where goods in State at contract or produced in State.

court_reasoning.text: Rejects second argument: New s.22 (1957, retrospective) deems sales inside State if delivered for consumption in State (Explanation sales), but sub-s.(2) says does not affect liability under other provisions; does not limit to Explanation sales.
court_reasoning.key_observation: After ban lifted, s.22 otiose for Art. 286(2); Act taxes on own terms.

court_reasoning.text: Declines intervener's plea to decide Art. 286(2) scope as unnecessary if Validation Act applies.

holdings.text: Sales Tax Laws Validation Act, 1956 s.2 applies to transactions; validates State tax on inter-State sales during specified period notwithstanding Art. 286(2).
Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 operates on own terms to tax these sales after ban lifted.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. United Motors (India) Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Held Explanation sales become intra-State by fiction, taxable by delivery State.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bengal Immunity Company Ltd. v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Explanation sales inter-State, not taxable under Art. 286(2) without Parliament lift.

precedents_cited.case_name: M. P. V. Sundararamier & Co. v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Upheld constitutionality of Validation Act; lifts Art. 286(2) ban, enables State laws on own terms; s.22 had positive content.

statutes_cited.name: Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Revision powers; charging section; definition of sale deems sales in State if goods there at contract; s.22 deems certain sales inside State but does not limit other liabilities.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art. 286(2) bans State tax on inter-State sales unless Parliament provides; Explanation to Art. 286(1)(a); certificate for appeal.

statutes_cited.name: Sales Tax Laws Validation Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Validates State taxes on inter-State sales April 1951-Sept 1955 notwithstanding court orders or Art. 286(2).

statutes_cited.name: Madras General Sales Tax (Amendment) Act, 1957
statutes_cited.relevance: Inserted new s.22 retrospectively from Jan 26, 1950.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; Sales Tax Laws Validation Act, 1956 applies to protect assessments on disputed sales; transactions taxable under Madras General Sales Tax Act as per its terms after ban lifted by Validation Act.

key_quotes.text: "Notwithstanding any judgment, decree or order of any court, no law of a State imposing or authorising the imposition of, a tax on the sale or purchase, of any goods where such sale or purchase took place in the course of inter-state trade or commerce during the period between the 1st day of April, 1951, and the 6th day of September, 1955, shall be deemed to be invalid..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.2 Validation Act, core of reasoning.

key_quotes.text: The effect of this provision is merely to liberate the State laws from the fetter placed on them by Art. 286(2) and to enable such laws to operate on their own terms.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains true scope of Validation Act.

key_quotes.text: After the removal of the fetter of Art. 286(2), the Act operating on its own terms makes the transactions in question liable to tax, and new s.22 makes no difference to that position.
key_quotes.speaker: court
